titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Warren H. Manning Papers, 1925-1928
titlestmt.subtitle: Manning, Warren H., Papers Ms1962-007

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-01-13T13:31-0500

titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections Ms1962-007

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.
did.abstract: This collection contains papers that document the involvement of Warren H. Manning in the beautification of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute campus and nearby buildings.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from Warren H. Manning Papers must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Warren H. Manning Papers, Ms1962-007, Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was acquired by Newman Library prior to 1962.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing, arrangement, and description of the Warren H. Manning was completed completed prior to January 2011. Additional description was completed in January 2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical
bioghist.p: Warren H. Manning was a well known Massachusetts landscape designer. He was a promoter of National Parks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection includes two of Manning's initial assessments of the Old Black Homestead and the Preston Cemetery on the Virginia Polytechnic Institute campus. Drawings of the Old Black Homestead are also present in this collection. There is also a copied Roanoke Times article, from May 2, 1928, describing the involvement of Warren H. Manning the landscape design of the school's campus. Lastly, there are copies of letters that Manning sent to Virginia Governor E. Lee Trinkle and to Virginia Tech President Julian Burruss, on the project at Virginia Tech.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this collection are arranged in chronological order. Undated materials are at the beginning.
